parse.title: List of films based on arts books

text.*:
This article may require cleanup to meet Wikipedia's quality standards. No cleanup reason has been specified. Please help improve this article if you can. (February 2011) (Learn how and when to remove this template message)

This is a list of films based on arts books.

This article contains Cyrillic text. Without proper rendering support, you may see question marks or boxes, misplaced vowels or missing conjuncts instead of Cyrillic letters.

References[edit]

Notes[edit]

  1. ^ Recipient of the Pulitzer Prize in 1991.
  2. ^ a b Hemingway was awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1954.
  3. ^ Fuentes was awarded the Cervantes Prize in 1987.
  4. ^ a b c Publication details for this title have been confirmed by the catalogue of the US Library of Congress. Source: Library of Congress Online Catalog.
  5. ^ a b Barker's sequel, The Ghost Road, was the recipient of the Booker Prize in 1995.
  6. ^ See List of films based on film books for more information on this title.
  7. ^ Recipient of the Pulitzer Prize in 1989.
  8. ^ "The BFI: Hedd Wyn (1992)". British Film Institute website. British Film Institute. 2010. Retrieved 2010-03-15. 
  9. ^ "countries within a country: Number10.go.uk". Prime Minister's Office. 10 January 2003. Archived from the original on 16 April 2010. Retrieved 2010-03-09. 
  10. ^ The families of Jim Morrison and Pamela Courson both objected to the book by Hopkins and Sugerman. The producers bought the rights to the notes, rather than the book itself. Source: Lavington (q.v.), p. 138.
  11. ^ a b Source: Lavington (q.v.), p. 148.
  12. ^ Recipient of the Governor General's Award in 1989.
  13. ^ Recipient of the Pulitzer Prize in 1990.
  14. ^ Inducted into the US National Film Registry in 2006.

Bibliography[edit]
